medical_history.chief_complaint: Resistance to TSH leading to euthyroid hyperthyrotropinemia in two siblings from consanguineous parents.
medical_history.history_of_present_illness: The condition was identified incidentally during a routine screening at age 50, revealing elevated TSH levels and normal thyroid hormone concentrations, consistent with partial resistance to TSH. Symptoms appeared not to compromise physical and mental development.
medical_history.past_medical_history: At age 50, the proband (DB) was found to have hypercholesterolemia and underwent thyroid function investigation, resulting in elevated TSH levels. A substitutive therapy with l-T4 was initiated, normalizing TSH levels after 6 months.
medical_history.family_history: Proband and his family were studied for thyroid function; two sons exhibited high TSH levels while the other family members showed no symptoms. The mutation was noted to be homozygous in two brothers (DS and DD), and heterozygous in other family members.
